Title.evidence: Cost-Effectiveness of Rubber Band Ligation Versus Hemorrhoidectomy for Grade III Hemorrhoids: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Conducted as a multicenter, randomised controlled trial in 10 Dutch hospitals, 79 adults with symptomatic grade III hemorrhoids were enrolled from September 2019 to November 2022.

Participants.evidence: 79 adults with symptomatic grade III hemorrhoids were enrolled from September 2019 to November 2022.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to RBL (n=46) or hemorrhoidectomy (n=33).

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the cost-effectiveness of rubber band ligation (RBL) compared to hemorrhoidectomy for grade III hemorrhoids.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were cost per quality-adjusted life year (QALY) gained and cost per recurrence avoided over 24 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 79 adults with symptomatic grade III hemorrhoids were enrolled from September 2019 to November 2022.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to RBL (n=46) or hemorrhoidectomy (n=33).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Hemorrhoidectomy resulted in a QALY difference of 0.08 (95% CI, 0.06–0.16; p=0.034) and a recurrence difference of 33.5% (95% CI, 15.3%–51.7%; p=0.002).
